plist.p: Good morning, everybody. Welcome here on this Thursday morning, very early in the morning. Thank you for joining us so early in the morning for the presentation of the Group Annual Results.

Just a quick word by way of introduction and then I'll give the floor to Bertrand Badré, our CFO, to make the presentation of results, and then Séverin Cabannes, Jean-François Sammarcelli and Bernardo Sanchez will answer your questions.

Now, I think it is worth reminding you about the fact that 2011 was indeed a very exceptional year with a lot happening on the political and economic standpoints, with lot of different crises, changes in the Mediterranean region, Fukushima, and also the crisis faced last summer and the crisis in the euro zone as well as concerning the sovereign debt.

And now on the whole, if the European Central Bank and European governments did make certain number of decisions that enabled things to sort of come back to normal at the beginning of this year, one still has to build confidence in the months to come, make sure that we have positive results, so that confidence is back.

And in this respect, before I talk about the results, let me first talk about our universal bank model, that model that we have at the Société Générale, and it has proved to be extremely solid, resilient and relevant. And it's true that all our teams have worked very hard to support our clients. We meet a lot of different customers every week, and I think that in such difficult times, our models can really make a difference.

And if we look at the results. Here we go. So into this very turbulent context, the financial results for the Group proved to be very resilient, €2.4 billion in the year with non-economic or non-recurring items, representing €850 million in the year. Therefore, we can say that the total results were €3.2 billion.

And now, these economic pressures were observed particularly in Q4, with non-recurring items representing €450 million with restructuring costs; revaluations of certain portfolios and the write-down of the Greek debt were mainly responsible for this. And as I underscored earlier, we must continue to do our business as a banker. Loans are increasing by 4.4% in French Networks and 4.7% in International Retail Banking.

And coming to France, I would just like to say that the momentum of loan intake inflows is very, very good, very solid, and it has outperformed economic performance, and at the end of the year, it was only – it was in Finland that loans were not going up. So therefore, I would say that our customers, both SMEs and large corporations, are being supported by us in the developments in their business and therefore results in Q4, including investments, underscore this point.

Now, you know that financing the economy will mean more reliance on markets and this is a key element. And you know that the regulatory framework has changed considerably, posing a major challenge for Europe. It's the consequence of Basel 3; less loans on bank balance sheets and market activities, and that is really the challenge that we face and that is the main challenge of our transformation.

So we have preserved the first plan in 2011, euro-denominated funds, so we were number three in that respect. And we are very satisfied with the beginning of the year, because we were able to conduct about 50 different operations with companies across Europe as well as financial institutions and European countries.

So we were able to combine this financing franchise and the market franchise, and it's also very important to underscore the fact that market activities are absolutely crucial for the economy and we must continues these activities, this business, in the euro zone.

In 2011, we pursued our transformation process despite the fact that it was a challenging year and we were able to produce tangible results. First of all, we managed to reduce our exposure to Greek sovereign debt. In particular, we have moved to a 75% markdown, so we only have a residual exposure of €307 million at end of January.

Furthermore, given that we have begun a process about three years ago, we also decided to reduce our risk profile in Corporate and Investment Banking. We were able to speed up asset disposals, representing €19 billion in all, at a limited cost in 2011. And therefore, we have reduced our balance sheet by €48 billion in six months, and the highlight of the quarter was as follows.

Well, as you know, there was the target of reaching 9% of core Tier 1 in Basel 2.5, and we managed to reach this 9% target six months ahead of schedule. We did this at the end of December 2011. So now, we've managed to move on and we are more forward-looking with Basel III requirements to be met.

Now, the first stage when it comes to this deleveraging, involves Société Générale CIB. You can see the reduction in the assets of SG CIB in the four quarters of 2011 with things beginning to pick up in Q4 of 2011. There was €13 billion of disposals of – NBI impact is just minus €116 million, €3 billion for natural amortizations and €6 billion by way of loan sales, and mainly, as I said, in Q4.

And these sales have improved our liquidity situation, because we have reduced our liquidity needs in U.S. dollars by €55 billion. The figure has moved from $100 billion to $45 billion. So we are no longer that dependent on U.S. money market fund resources, so we will maintain this independence in the future.

Now, as to management of our balance sheet, we have managed to reap the benefits of these risk-weighted assets management. Now, as you can see, we have managed to proceed with a very strict control of our risk-weighted assets in the different branches, with growth at 2% a year. And we have managed to significantly reduce our RWAs in the – French Retail Banking by minus 13% of CIB – minus 13%.

Now, if we look at the impact, this is the bottom of the slide, if you look at the positive impact on core Tier 1 of 50 basis points for CIB. Now, it was decided to retain our earnings within the Bank, which has provided us with an additional 50 basis points for core Tier 1 and there was – and increase in scrip dividends. This was the choice that was made by our shareholders, to accept the scrip dividend option for dividends for 2010. Then we also managed to gain 11 bps through the buyback of our hybrids and we were also able to improve our Basel II ratio by 130 basis points.

And then of course there is the negative impact of Basel 2.5, costing 81 bps, with €25 billion. That was the total cost. We have managed to reduce our business, reduce our assets faster than expected, and we have a new mechanism now. And we have implemented this new regulation and therefore reached the 9% target.

We are very pleased to have reached this 9% target, because it just goes to show that we were able to deleverage our balance sheets, and this can also be seen through the reduction of our funding profile. Our funding profile has improved considerably. At the end of 2011, it was at €636 billion. And I think we can do even better. We can improve our balance sheet even further. Long-term resources are going down, and generally speaking, our long-term resources are higher than consumption. And short-term funding represents only 19% of funded balance sheet. We have a stable deposit base as well.
Now, as to the long-term funding program for 2012, it's between €10 billion to €15 billion. We have already pre-funded €2.6 billion, and in 2012, we have already funded €2.8 billion to date.

Now, as to exposure to sovereign debt, particularly in the five high-risk countries, exposure is rather limited now. You can see here the change, the trend, from end of December 2010 to the beginning of 2012, and this is for the five GIIPS countries. €307 million for Greek government bonds. We don't have any exposure as far as Portugal goes – is concerned. And you can see that we have a very limited exposure when it comes to Ireland, Italy and Spain. €300 million for Ireland, €1.4 billion for Italy and €700 million for Spain.
We have short maturities for these portfolios. 32% of exposure is maturing in less than 18 months, so these figures will automatically go down in the months to come.

Concerning trading activities, these figures vary, and for the five countries, the figure – the trading book exposure is €1.1 billion. As to our Greek subsidiary, exposure went down considerably, from €3.5 million to €2.6 million in one year, so we also proceeded to weight further allocations of provisions, bringing the loan coverage ratio to 35%. And we have also reduced reliance on Group funding, down to €168 million at end of 2011, with a policy of deposit inflows that are at €1.8 billion.

Now, if you look at the portfolio on the whole, and if you look at exposure to private debt of risky countries, I would say that this exposure is fairly moderate, and that is excellent news for the years to come.
I'd like to give the floor now to Bertrand, who will give you more details about our results.

Thank you, Frédéric. I think that the key points have already been discussed. Let's look at the details a bit. The salient point, so what you pointed out, the fact that we had achieved a risk-weighted – we at 9% core capital. We'll spend a bit of time looking at some of the one-offs or exceptional items.

But before going into those points, we would like to briefly review the five-year banking income for the Bank, and we see that we've had something pretty steady through 2011 and despite the sharp shocks, as Frédéric pointed out at the start, which affected all of our businesses, not only in CIB, which was initially impacted, we saw that over the past three years, Group revenues are around €25 billion, and the decline in 2011 was, to a large extent, reduced. This is due to the resilience or growth of Retail Banking in France and abroad, and the strong performance by Specialized Financial Services, which in 2011 largely offset the shock which came about with – in a very active way as we deleveraged CIB in H2.

Now, let's look at the results, looking at the consolidated results. Here you see Net Banking income, as I said, declined very slightly. If you look at it on like-for-like basis, by 2.5% or 3%, largely due to the decline in CIB because of market conditions and deleveraging and, to a lesser extent, the GIIPS-type businesses, this is our securities business and management, while other activities continued to raise the Net Banking income. On the operating expenses line for our costs, here we – a direct reading of this shows a rise in expenses, either on a like-by-like basis or on common terms.

But if you look at this in greater detail, you see a strong negative impact in 2011 which we allocated provisions to in 2011 for the restructuring we've announced in CIB, and when we adjust for that, when we adjust for the systemic taxes in France and to a lesser extent in the UK and Germany, then we have 1% growth, but minus 4% in Q4.

Bear in mind here that you see the Bank's reaction, which was not only to deleverage, starting with CIB, but also to vigorously control costs in the second part of the year. I think this is a major message. The cost of risk is up 4%. That's a face value. But it was – give us two contrasted pictures. First, you have the very significant impact of the provisions for Geniki and also for the €830 million for Greek debt. But we have a 20% decline in the cost of risk, including a risk for the year.

So this has impacted the operating result. We have the two factors standing (18:01) against each other, but the €100-million result and the full-year results are explained to a larger extent by a set of exceptional items. So this shows the slight difference between the consensus figures and our figures. So I think that if you look at it in the results, it's less significant.

What are the key points here? The first, unfortunately, is something we've begun to be accustomed to since the start of the crisis. This year, it was a positive impact; in other years, it was a negative €700 million for the quarter and €1.1 billion for our exceptional items.

The second exceptional item, as I pointed out, is the depreciation, €192 million, up to 75% impairment for Greek debt, as Frédéric pointed out. The restructuring charges, including €230 million for CIB alone, and a number of adjustments in goodwill for losses on securities. These are small amounts, but added up, they come to close to €350 million.

And finally, deleveraging expenses, because deleveraging isn't simply trimming the balance sheet, but as Frédéric pointed out, it does have a cost. It was extremely lucky (19:26) because we are able to divest ourselves of assets in a very positive way, better than expected (19:33). €250 million in core debts] (19:36).

And the last exceptional item I'd like to mention, I'll get back to that later, is the impairment on assets managed on a run-off basis, and we'll be looking at that later. €400 million before taxes. Now, if we adjust, I know this is going to be a complicated test to adjust this, but if you adjust our quarterly and full-year result for the sum of these positive and negative items, the net result would be €3.2 billion going for the year, and for Q4, we'd be closer to €600 million. And this shows the underlying performance of the businesses.

The next page shows the decline in cost of risk across our businesses. A slight inflection in France, as we saw, with a slight uptick in H2. Regarding 2012 perspectives, so far we haven't seen any deterioration. We have remained vigilant in the conditions of economic uncertainty. That stands to reason. But now, we anticipate that we'd see the same moderate levels as at the end of 2011.

Now, let's look at the French Networks. The situation is quite clear. Net Banking income higher, driven by a very successful duration of Société Marseillaise de Crédit, which is boosting NBI, but we also have the increase in the costs relating to that. There is another factor here, and this is IT spending to ensure for conversion to the IT platforms. Société Credit du Nord and SocGen in France, the cost of risk is lower, and now the NBI shows a higher financial result. And here, we see the strong financial performance here with growth in deposits higher than growth in loans, 8% up deposits, 4% in loans. And as Frédéric pointed out, we are funding the French economy. The loan-to-deposit ratio, which is an important indicator you are tracking, it rose considerably over the year.

Now, if we look at International Networks, here we see that in commercial terms, despite the adverse situation in some countries, Frédéric pointed this out, we have events in some countries in sub-Saharan Africa. The consequences of the Arab Spring and the challenging conditions in Greece and Romania now, all of this isn't translated into a (22:24) figure, which is still strong, and we have revenues rising in all countries except for Greece and Romania.

On the other hand, despite the geopolitical context, we have strong growth in our Net Banking income in the Mediterranean Basin and in most of Central and Eastern Europe. The net result is €673 million, exclusive of Greece. Greece is important because just over half of the result is offset by losses incurred in Greece due to the impairment we've taken, as Frédéric mentioned earlier.

The key point regarding our International Networks is the tight management approach as we ensure the proper balance between loans and deposits. Here we see that it's not the case in absolutely every country, but overall, we have a 99% ratio and we want this to weigh less on the Group. So Group funding, once again, was reduced in all of the international countries.

We have a third major business here. This is CIB, and this is obviously the business which was most severely affected by the highly graded situation in H2. The first half of the year was good. The second part of the year saw a dislocation of markets and a significant slowdown in capital markets, with very little in the way of issuance in this environment, which is very challenging.

Nevertheless, in those conditions we took reactive actions here, reducing our size of our balance sheet, reducing short-term funding for market activities, and strong deleveraging in our various activities. Here, we had net revenues roughly the same, especially for equities, 4% comparison to two years. A slight dip in Q4 versus Q3, but the equity business was driven by our equity derivatives franchise.

The fixed income area was also highly impacted obviously, with a decline in comparable conditions or similar to the market. Here again, a strong rebound in Q4. Unfortunately that was offset by the weakness in the markets and issuance in terms of financing and advisory. Here again the year was marked by the environment. Our structured finance franchise made it possible to see a decline limited to 16%, so CIB proved resilient across its components.

CIB deleveraged and CIB confirmed the strategy commenced four years ago with systematic de-risking. We tried to illustrate that with the three indicators you see on the chart at the top. And we could discuss the relevance (25:39) all pointing in the same direction in a very significant way.

Now, if we look at the activities being managed on a run-off basis, I see there were questions regarding this. So the quarter didn't continue the €100 million per quarter rate you are familiar with. There were number of points here.

The first thing I'd like to point out is the deleveraging focus first on the activities operated on a run-off basis with €13 billion in – so we see the two impacts are disposals and amortization, and the net value of USD-denominated (26:26) was around 68% (26:29) year-on-year. And we are going to be continuing looking at this with CDOs, and the key point here was the valuation of our CDOs and their hedges.

Now, we have a number of points. First, we adjusted our CDO values in parallel with the (26:55) assessments. We didn't change method. We adjusted in the parameters, and that's the first point. Second, we had a specific thing we looked at a good deal of – our exposure is hedged with the NBI(a)s. And here, we deemed it prudent to move to a full recording of the mark-to-market of CDS rather than neutralizing it after taking account of notional amounts of the hedge and determining our monocline reserve as we did previously.

So remember that now the market has a stronger approach to NBI(a)s, first in light of what the U.S. authorities could do going forward. And second, due that – the fact that there were a number of computations, most recently with another French bank in recent week. So the NBI(a) situation is a bit better.

The mark-to-market value of our CDSs was positive and has now become significantly negative, because we didn't book the gain. Now, as a matter of conservatism, we are booking the loss. So this is a €400-million impact on our value before taxes, and this will in future have a different impact.

The valuation of CDOs is done. The additional impairment is not something which is going to fluctuate each quarter. On the other hand, there will be a possible impact in future, depending on how the market looks at the NBI(a)s and therefore the value of the CDSs. So there could be volatility in that area in terms of hedging our exposure to NBI(a)s.

The second point we'd like to resist (28:35) upon today is that we have to examine in greater detail. (28:40) I think we have to do with greater rigor now. What we have in the €17 billion in assets in bad bank. Now, we see the €17 billion is the sum of two pools of assets of different qualities. On the one hand, you have over €12 billion, just over €12 billion in assets, which would be called good bank assets, even though technically they're in the bad bank.

Now, these assets have little or nothing in the way of expected losses. It costs very little in terms of capital allocations, and we can do our arbitrage looking at the various components, as we would do with other portfolios in the Bank.

So I think that the €12 billion, although technically still in the bad bank, should not be considered to be bad-bank assets. The key issue here has to do with the €5 billion remaining here. As you know, the key questions are the RMBSs and the CDOs, which account for – about half of that is U.S. RMBSs and CDOs for U.S. RMBSs, and this is what we'll be managing through the end of 2013. So we are going to be focusing our attention on this in the coming quarters.

Now, regarding Specialized Financial Services, the positive point is that we are on the right path this year after a number of difficult years. So the path is positive and all of the Specialized Financial Services areas, despite the constraint of stability in long-term (30:30) standing, now the key point recently was securitization. It was successful in Germany, just under €700 million. So this business can be funded itself, and insurance was a very, very good year. Perhaps the best ever. We haven't got enough hindsight yet to look at that, despite the condition in life insurance in France.

And if you look at last point, these are the Financial Services. So very good work, good inflows, Private Banking and TCW stabilization in a new hedge. And at Amundi, we have no change in the contribution. The net income is affected by a €65-million goodwill write-down and a number of minor points, joined with disputes and other things. But once again in the year and the end of the year, the performance of these businesses was very positive.

Now, there were three more points that we have to look at before I give the floor to Frédéric. Here we see systemic taxes and the NBI(a) impact and revaluation of own debt, the 2011 impact in costs was (32:04) France and the UK, and 2011, that cost of risk including Greek sovereign exposure is €190 million, of which €162 million in Q4, Group net income, as you see.
Now, Frédéric?

Yes, I'd like to wrap up here. And 2011 was a turning point, as I think we saw, and we were able to show the resilience, also robustness, of our universal banking model and our banking areas. So we can look forward to 2012 with confidence, although with 2012, we still have limited visibility. We will continue to accentuate optimizing the Bank's balance sheet and also developing our businesses, our franchises, with a focus on the customer in the strategy.

What does this mean for our business line? In the French Network, we will continue to focus on quality of service and also combining our strength with the three bank names internationally. We want to consolidate our growth strategy in line with each country, and also manage our risk areas in CIB. We want to continue the transformation, managing the situation with the environment, as I explained. The start of the year has been good in market areas and we're continuing to develop our credit distribution model and we are continuing to sell some CIB assets.

And finally, in Financial Services, asset management and insurance, we anticipate higher results, developing this in synergy across the key business lines in the Group. So in 2012, we're going to continue our balance sheet optimization and continue to improve the financial structure in terms of equity, capital and liquidity, and continue the efforts begun in 2011 to reach our target for core Tier 1 according to Basel 3. We are at 9%, six months ahead of time. So I think we've completed that chapter, and now in the next few years we have to transform our Group. This affects all of our banks, all the banks, in what will probably remain an uncertain volatile environment.
So now we are ready to take your questions.
Okay, Mr. Chedeville?

Yes, good morning. I have a few small questions regarding to your risk-weighted assets. I just want to understand, because I wasn't sure that I understood the logic behind it, so it's probably very technical. But would it be possible to explain this in simple terms?

Regarding the CDOs, you said the methodology for valuation of the CDOs hasn't changed. Well, currently the value should have – has been – has deteriorated (35:33). What parameters has it been deteriorated on? I don't understand, because when you say you are taking the mark-to-market value of the hedges, but typically when a hedge is well designed, it's suppose to hedge or offset the loss in value of the underlying asset.

So logically, they should be symmetrical, otherwise it serves no purpose to hedge unless if the insurer defaults, but apparently you didn't take that into account with the potential default of the hedge. So I don't see why you have a negative impact of €400 million, because typically when the issuer – the insurer can meet its responsibilities, the valuation should be symmetrical.

Another point. You said that in Q4 2011, the equity signed to the assets managed on a run-off basis are €4 billion. They were being managed on a run-off basis. Okay, so we've got €4 billion for that, of which €2.9 billion for the CDOs, for RMBSs. So this leaves €1.1 billion for the other assets, the €12 billion that you claim are sound assets. So that's €1 billion to €12 billion.

The question is, why you are selling them? Because €1 billion to €12 billion; that's the type of weighting you could have for any asset class. So I don't see why you are focusing on them when you are trying – claiming to improve your ratios, because they shouldn't improve your capital adequacy. Ratios is not any more than if you were to sell of your conventional loan portfolios.

Now, another technical point, in the footnote, you write, in computing that €4 billion, that it accounts to 8% of net risk-weighted assets, 8% of RWAs. Are you saying 8% for the other businesses? Or I thought you were at 7%. Is this a new development with Basel III or is this something specific for these assets? So I think it might be good to have your insight on that point as well.

And to wrap up on CIB, regarding Q4, with the pullback in funding, it's significant, down 40%, if I read that properly, because I did it very quickly. So the 16% decline for the full year is primarily what happened at the end of the year. So what portion of this can you attribute to the overall economic situation, which would appear to be fairly stable? If we could compare you to one of your competitors with general funding, the deleverage has just begun, did something go wrong or was there something specific in your organization?

And one more. I think I'll stop here. No, no, I do have one more question. Now, regarding insurance, do you anticipate selling credit portfolios to insurance companies? This is becoming a fashionable thing and wouldn't it make sense to do arbitrage in this way in selling credit loan portfolios to insurance subsidiaries, which would manage these on a solvency basis, because insurance companies tend to be well capitalized?

One last question regarding Greece now. Unless I'm mistaken, because I haven't had a chance to find it, I don't see any information on Q4 specifically. Okay, maybe it's in there and I didn't see it, but information on the cost of risk and net income. Maybe it's in another line, but I didn't see Greece results in – for Q4?

Okay. I'm going to let Bertrand answer specifically regarding CDOs and I'm going to let Séverin discuss CDOs. And Mr. Oudéa speaking, I'm going to just talk about the portfolio run on a run-off basis and insurance. You are precisely correct here. And this is what we want to show when we make this distinction.

We have €12 billion which are investment grade assets and there is no reason fundamentally to deal with them differently from any the other loan in the Bank's balance sheet. It just turns out that four years ago, a request was made that securitization-type projects be segmented in this specific set of reports, but over the subsequent four years or 3.5 years, the track record of those products, the economy and the underlyings show that these assets are actually investment-grade.

Indeed, as Bertrand pointed out, we manage them exactly like any loan. It's not a major issue in terms of capital constraints, no more than anything else, nor is it an issue in terms of liquidity in light of what we've sold because of the €12 billion. There's only €8.5 billion that actually requires a capital allocation. That's very small in light of the whole. So as we explained, this is simply a standard way of managing these assets, and whether or not we sell them will depend on market opportunities and management decisions.

Then we have the €4.9 billion, of which €2.9 billion in UMBS (41:41) CDOs which aren't investment-grade and which could lead to additional allocation supervisions with a capital deduction now under Basel 2.5, and under Basel III, it's going to be higher. So that's what we are going to be working on with a limited impact on capital, because now these are activities which have a cost in terms of capital allocation, but the amount itself is quite limited in light of what we've already done on the portfolio and the provisions we've already booked. Now, that's what we can say about the portfolio being managed on a run-off basis.

Now regarding insurance more generally, I think we have to move – we have to have a clear view of the origination distribution model under Basel III, and this is a fundamental challenge for Europe. Basel III means that the banks, I believe, will continue to originate credit and will often hold them for a significant period of time, especially if you look at project financing, perhaps during the build phase when cash flows aren't certain, when there are construction-related risks on the projects, where the risk is a function of our assessment of the country, the technology, the project, the sponsor, et cetera, and then we will be distributing more in the way of the launch, especially when the cash flow is coming in to investors who are obviously interested in an area in a period when euros are going to remain low across a larger range of assets and when liquidity is high.

So you have to bear in mind that these are assets which could be sold, but investors have to be in a position to understand them. So insurance companies are one among many potential types of investors. Some are currently taking on the capabilities required with the funds or anything it takes. That is only one type of potential investor, and not others.

But it's important for this to be put in place swiftly in Europe. So there are three or four years for Europe to be able to fund itself this way in the run up to the Basel III requirements. This is in the interest of many parties, including customers who can do this, because going through a bank for this type intermediation could be expensive in light of the constraints on the banking industry going forward. Now, Société Générale makes its own decisions. We – remember that our insurance company is just one among many on the market.

Now, maybe we could get back to the CDOs. This is technical issue. So the valuation of our CDOs is based on a set of parameters, as you know, including final loss, the rate of which those developments occur, and this is done, as we do it. (45:25) have their methods and what we saw was that conditions were tighter, and we are just lining up with overall conditions. There is no change in method at all. And these are things which are done on a systematic – not on a one-off basis each quarter. So hedges may not be perfect hedges. So if we were perfectly hedged in terms of maturity and amount, that would be – wouldn't be the – that isn't the case. So once again, we recognize a loss.

So the real problem is properly recognizing and identifying the NBI(a) risk, will the company default, and when. So remember, the CDSs don't have an infinite maturity either. So you have a large number of factors, meaning that once again, as a matter of conservatism, we readjusted significantly to reduce this. And as the model – if the situations on the market were to change over the next six months, we'd be recognizing a gain. This is complex. It's not all that easy to explain, but there is no fundamental change in method. This is simply to deal with your question.
Now, there is a question regarding the cost under Basel III. So it's 125%. No change in method. So I think those are the only questions I am to answer.
Yes, so Séverin, could you say something about funding?

So the question was were there exceptional items which affected our NBI or – well, in Q4. Well, as we accelerated sale of part of our loan portfolio, we sold €6 billion and the NBI impact was mentioned here, with the reduction in the last quarter. So if you adjust for the adjustment of that, we'd be looking at an NBI decline of 10% for a year, and especially in the last quarter.

Now, bear in mind that our activity, we are very strong in structured finance. And in the last quarter of last year, there were no major projects funded. So maybe this is because there were no major projects in structured finance there, and our global capital market activities were obviously affected here with debt issuance and equity issuance. But as Frédéric said, this year has started up well. So apart from deleveraging and apart for the impact we mentioned on NBI, there is nothing specific.
Now regarding Greece in Q4, Bernardo, in Greece in Q4?

Our provisions were what we – compliant with the rate we had mentioned before. So we allocated to risk and it was between €75 million and €80 million for the quarter. So a bit less than the slightly positive operating income.

Yes, Pascal Decque from Cheuvreux. I have number of questions. There aren't that many of us here in the room, so I'll take advantage of that with a number of questions. First, with Basel III, I didn't hear you mention a new target. Now that we've moved beyond Basel 2.5, have you got more specific figures for your common equity Tier 1 under Basel III? Apparently there are some slight changes in potential treatment of insurance for you, so it's (49:51) just 10 basis points. Has that changed?
Another question for Basel III. If your objectives at 1 January are end December 2013 for Greece, what's your run rate with Genesis? Is it still €100 million in provisions for a year?

Then regarding the deleveraging, you didn't mention a figure for losses on sales of assets. We thought there was €163 million in the portfolio and BNP sold about the same, had about the same amount, and they anticipate another €650 million in losses in 2012.
